body: "Publicly" is probably never going to be a thing in Syncthing, for philosophical reasons. Some sort of quicker centralized deployment (for use in businesses etc) might be a thing. Removing authentication there is probably not the truth though, rather *adding* things like AD integration and so on. (Which is way out of scope for the moment, just saying that's where you end up when the "for business" use case gets analyzed.)
This goes again syncthings security model where things have to be acknowledgedâ€‹ and agreed by both sides. I don't think syncthing will ever support the concept of anything public.

The philosophy point is clear, so sorry for flogging an already dead horse:
I think the suggestion is not to automatically add other devices, but to broadcast some kind of "I am here" message, resulting in every other instance hearing this to prompt the user whether he wants to accept this device or not.

Edit: Good point about prompts potentially being overwhelming in a corporate environment - it would however be very much fun to find out how many Syncthing users are around on campus this way :D

I think we do that already, or used to do that, as you add a device it suggests the device ids that are on the local network. I don't think "I'm here" prompts would work in a corporate/university environment where there are potentially multiple users you are unaware off.
Yeah it's browser dependent but the discovery broadcasts serve this purpose and the "add device" dialog will autocomplete device ids with that knowledge. But it's not especially discoverable.
If that is the issue here, we should probably just be clearer in that dialog. Show the list of detected but not added devices explicitly, allowing click to add or something.

Cool, I didn't know about that feature - I would wager to guess neither do most other users. In a quick look at the documentation I didn't find this feature either. So making this easier to discover and/or documenting it would certainly be nice, as it is definitely a useful feature (meaning I can start spying on my colleagues :D ).
That's really nice, but I'm another person who was completely unaware of this!

Yeah, so clearly that's crap and we should fix that. I'm just waiting for OP to chime in with "exactly, that's what I mean" (so we can clarify the issue) or "no dudes, I'm saying you need public shares" or whatever.

@imsodin you're right. 
(Sorry folks I can't respond any more right now, I'm driving ðŸš˜)

PS: How is it a security problem if a feature like this would be an optional feature disabled by default? And I'm not looking to automatically add devices... I'm looking to automatically find devices that are publicly saying the same "I'm here" message.

rename.from: Feature Suggestion: Network and Subnet Shares
rename.to: Show "nearby devices" in add device dialog

body: Retitling for clarity. This one should be easy as we already have the required info available in the GUI javascript.

issue.title: gui: Add dropdown menu to choose discovered devices to device modal (fixes #4157)

issue.body:
### Purpose
#4157

### Testing
Manual poking around.

### Screenshots

http://i.imgur.com/8TjO0Q8.png
http://i.imgur.com/iEIPV0w.png

### Implementation

I needed the isEmptyObject function within the modal view. I don't know what the "correct" way of doing this in JS/Angular is, I just assigned it to $scope.isEmptyObject.

body: Has anyone seen this implemented yet? Just curious. :(

> Has anyone seen this implemented yet? Just curious. :(

Yes? The commit implementing this is linked just above your post and the feature also made it into the latest stable release ([v0.14.32](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/releases/tag/v0.14.32)).
It depends on the definition of "this". We implemented what we interpreted would be useful from your ticket, not necessarily what you expected.
